game:botanicalleathers-quickstartguide-t: BOTANICAL LEATHERS "From Petal to Pelt: The Art of Vegetable Tanning." Here lies the secret to crafting leather from plants, allowing one to thrive without the slaughter of beasts. For too long, survival has been synonymous with the hunt. Driven by a desire for peace, I turned to the flora. Hidden within cactus fibers and fungal flesh lies a strength equal to any pelt. This almanac guides you through these cruelty-free alternatives. TABLE OF CONTENTS I. THE FUNGAL PATH (Mushrooms) II. THE FRUIT PATH (Apple, Mango) III. THE FIBER PATH (Pineapple, Cactus) IV. THE CORK PATH (Oak) IV. FINAL TANNING (Common Step)
game:botanicalleathers-fungalpath-text: I. THE FUNGAL PATH Fast and porous. The damp corners of the world offer the quickest route to leather. Fungi, when treated correctly, possess a surprising elasticity similar to skin. 1. Saturation (Barrel) Ordinary mushrooms are brittle. To toughen them, they must be submerged in a Barrel of Water. Let them drink until they become bloated Soaked Mushrooms. 2. Extraction (Press) These sodden lumps must be purged. Place them in a Fruit Press to separate the solid matter. Note: The dark Fungal Residue that flows out is rich in nutrients and serves as an excellent starter for Compost. 3. Binding (Grid) Recover the Pressed Mash. On a crafting table, use a Hammer to beat the fibers together. They will fuse into a Fungal Prepared Hide.
game:botanicalleathers-fruitpath-text: II. THE FRUIT PATH From Sweetness to Strength. Abundance often brings waste, but the resourceful naturalist sees opportunity. The leftover pomace of Apples and Mangoes can be transformed into a leather-like material through heat and binding. 1. Preparation (Press & Knife) We seek the dry fiber, not the juice. First, process fruits in a Fruit Press. Take the resulting mash and refine it with a Knife to create Sliced Fruit Pulp. 2. The Alchemical Bond (Pot) Pulp alone crumbles. It needs a binder to become skin. Boil the sliced pulp in a Cooking Pot along with Resin or Beeswax to create the botanical paste. 3. Shaping (Bowl & Grid) Warning: Time is of the essence. The mixture is too viscous to pour. Use an Empty Bowl to scoop the Hot Botanical Paste directly from the pot. Place this filled bowl into the crafting grid and strike it with a Hammer to forge the Fruit Prepared Hide. (If the paste hardens, simply reheat it).
game:botanicalleathers-fiberpath-text: III. THE FIBER PATH The Spine and the Leaf. Where fruit offers softness, the desert and the tropics offer resilience. The tough fibers of Pineapple Leaves and Cactus yield the most durable botanical hides, structured to withstand the elements. 1. Fracture (Press & Knife) The structural integrity of these plants must be broken. First, crush the harvested fibers in a Fruit Press. Take the resulting mash and slice it finely with a Knife to prepare it for binding. Bonus: The liquid residue extracted is a potent compost starter. 2. Fusion (Pot) Like the fruit method, these fibers require a binder. Boil the sliced pulp in a Cooking Pot with Resin or Beeswax until it forms a thick, hot paste. 3. Shaping (Bowl & Grid) While the mixture is bubbling, use an Empty Bowl to scoop up the Hot Botanical Paste. Immediately place the filled bowl onto the crafting grid and strike it with a Hammer. The impact aligns the fibers into a Fiber Prepared Hide.
game:botanicalleathers-corkpath-text: IV. THE CORK PATH The Tree's Armor. Oak offers a unique bark, cork, which once treated, becomes supple and waterproof. This is a complex method that demands patience and mastery of fire. 1. Harvesting (Grid) Strip the bark from a fallen log. In the crafting grid, combine an Oak Log with an Axe and a Hammer to obtain Raw Oak Bark (and retrieve your debarked log). 2. Softening (Barrel & Drying) Raw bark is brittle. Submerge it in a Barrel of Water (72h) to soften it. Once soaked, remove it and let it dry (24h) to obtain a stable prepared bark. 3. Steaming (Fire) To give the cork its final elasticity, it must be heated. Assemble 8 prepared barks into a Cork Bundle. Place this bundle in a pitkiln for steaming. Then, disassemble the steamed bundle. 4. Rolling & Assembly Strike the steamed bark with a Hammer to flatten it into a Cork Sheet. Finally, use a Knife and Resin (and Linen for the very large pieces) to assemble these sheets into a Prepared Cork Hide.
game:botanicalleathers-finaltanning-text: IV. FINAL TANNING The Great Preservation. Whether formed from fungus, fruit, or fiber, your Prepared Hide is still organic matter, prone to decay. It lacks the permanence of true leather. Observation on Mass As you have likely discovered, the quantity of material used (Number of Paste Bowls or Mushroom Mash) determines the size of the resulting hide (Small, Medium, Large, Huge). 1. Curing (Barrel) To lock the fibers in place, the hide must be treated chemically. Seal it in a Barrel containing Limewater or Diluted Borax. 2. The Transition After sealing, the botanical nature is masked. The item transforms into a standard Soaked Hide. From this point on, treat it exactly as you would an animal skin: Scrape it, and tan it (Oak/Acacia) to finish your work.
